title-group.article-title: On the effects of non-homogeneous materials on the vibrations and static stability of tapered shafts

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, C. S. Mott Engineering and Science Center, Kettering University, Flint, MI, USA
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Michigan, W. E. Lay Automotive Laboratory, Ann Arbor, MI, USA

author-notes.corresp: Arnaldo J Mazzei Jr, Department of Mechanical Engineering, C. S. Mott Engineering and Science Center, Kettering University, 1700 University Avenue, Flint, MI 48504, USA Email: amazzei@kettering.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Shafts loaded by axial compressive forces constitute an area of considerable technical importance. The static stability and transverse vibrations of such shafts are the subjects of this work. Occasionally the shafts are tapered and of interest is the effect of employing functionally graded materials (FGMs), with properties varying in the axial direction, on the buckling load and lowest bending natural frequency. Here the shaft cross section is taken to be circular and three types of taper are treated: linear, sinusoidal and exponential. The shafts are assumed to have the same volume and length and to be subjected to a constant axial force. Euler–Bernoulli theory is used with the axial force handled by a buckling type approach. The problems that arise are computationally challenging but an efficient numerical strategy employing MAPLE®’s two-point boundary value solver has been developed. Typical results for a linear tapered pin–pin shaft where one end radius is twice the other, and the FGM model varies in a power law fashion with material properties increasing in the direction of increasing area, include doubling of the buckling load and first bending frequency increase of approximately 43%, when compared with a homogeneous tapered shaft.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: This work is concerned with the buckling and transverse vibration of tapered shafts, both homogeneous and non-homogeneous.

One strategy to avoid resonances is to shift natural frequencies outside operational ranges. This could be possibly achieved by employing laminated composites, but they are prone to stress discontinuities and delamination. As pointed out by Birman and Byrd (2007), these difficulties can be avoided by using functionally graded materials (FGMs), in which property variations are continuous.

Here the non-homogeneity is modeled by the use such materials, with material properties varying in the axial direction (see Birman and Byrd (2007) for more information on modeling and analysis of FGM). A brief, and by no means exhaustive, survey of previous work is given below.

There is a considerable body of research on the buckling of homogeneous tapered shafts, motivated, in part, by the search for optimum columns (i.e. for a given volume and length, what is the maximum buckling load?). See Lee et al. (2006) for numerous references on this. Buckling of variable cross-section columns was also treated by, for example, Darbandi et al. (2010), Totry et al. (2007) and Rahai and Kazemi (2008). The latter work pointed out that tapered shapes are widely used in buildings, bridges, bearings, etc. Lee and Oh (2000) developed numerical methods for calculating the elastic and buckling load of tapered columns with regular polygon cross sections and constant volume.
Work on the buckling of structures made of FGMs has also been done. See, for example, Naei et al. (2007).

Huang and Li (2011) discussed a novel analytic approach to determine the buckling instability of Euler–Bernoulli columns with arbitrary axial non-homogeneity and/or varying cross section. For various columns the governing differential equation for buckling with varying flexural rigidity was reduced to a Fredholm integral equation. Critical buckling load could be determined by requiring that the resulting integral equation possess a non-trivial solution.

Singh and Li (2009) presented a mathematical model which is capable of computing the buckling loads of uniform and non-uniform functionally graded columns in the axial direction. The columns with spatial variation of flexural stiffness, due to material grading and/or non-uniform shape, were approximated by an equivalent column with piecewise constant geometrical and material properties.

Free vibration of axially functionally graded beams (FGBs) with non-uniform cross section was treated by Huang and Li (2010). An approach was developed to solve for the natural frequencies of beams with various end supports. The equations of motion were transformed into Fredholm integral equations, which were solved by expanding the mode shapes in power series. The natural frequencies were determined by requiring the existence of a non-trivial solution for the resulting system of linear algebraic equations. The method was found to have fast convergence and good accuracy. Results showed that a FGB with axial non-homogeneity, where the cross-sectional area and area moment of inertia are unchanged, could benefit the design of non-homogeneous beams for certain purposes.

Transverse vibrations of tapered shafts have received attention. See, for example, the works of Kim et al. (1999), Elishakoff and Rollot (1999) and Elishakoff (2005). In the latter work, the flexural stiffness was frequently taken to be a polynomial function of the axial coordinate and analytical solutions were found.

Atmane et al. (2011) conducted a theoretical investigation of free vibration of a FGB with a variable cross section. It was assumed that material properties varied along the beam thickness according to exponential distributions. On using integrated forms of Young’s modulus and mass density, the governing equation was reduced to an ordinary differential equation with constant coefficients in the spatial coordinate and analytical solutions for the frequencies were obtained. Results showed that the non-uniformity in the cross section and the non-homogeneity in material properties influenced the natural frequencies. With all other parameters remaining the same, the frequencies of the non-homogeneous beams changed (increased or decreased) by the same percentage amount as those of the homogeneous beams.

Owing to the lack of analytic solutions, in general, addressing issues such as optimization is problematic. Here some numerical explorations are presented. Promising trends could be further explored using optimization techniques, but that is the topic of a future work.

In this work linear, sinusoidal and exponential types of taper are treated. All shafts have the same volume and length. They are subjected to a constant axial force. Two FGM models are used. Basic goals are the determination of the effects of the FGM on the buckling load and lowest bending frequency.

The underlying mechanical modeling is Euler–Bernoulli theory with the axial force introduced by a buckling type approach. The governing equations are partial differential equations (PDEs) with coefficients that vary in a complex fashion. In general, analytic solutions cannot be found and numerical methods must be used. Rather than developing a finite element, or finite difference scheme, here a strategy is employed for obtaining results using MAPLE®’s two-point boundary value solver (available at http://www.maplesoft.com).
The boundary conditions are taken to be pin–pin.

sec.title: 2. Modeling
sec.p:
The equation of motion for a shaft in bending under axial load can be derived via a Newton–Euler approach applied to a differential element of the beam (see Figure 1, which shows the underlying variables).(A detailed derivation focusing on a rotating shaft under axial loading and bending is given by the present authors in a previous work: Mazzei and Scott (2008).) The equation, based on Euler–Bernoulli theory, is given below. The axial force (here compressive: F) enters by a buckling modeling type approach (details can be found in Weaver et al. (1990)): (1)∂2∂x2(EI∂2w∂x2)+F∂2w∂x2+ρA∂2w∂t2=f Figure 1.
Beam configuration element.

No assumption was made for the material type in the derivation of Equation (1). Thus, it can be either a homogeneous or non-homogeneous material. In this work both types are considered. The non-homogeneous materials utilized are FGMs (see, for example, Miyamoto et al. (1999)).

In the following an exploration is made on the joint use of tapering and non-homogeneous materials. Circumstances may dictate the use, and shape, of tapers. Three types are considered: conical (linear), sinusoidal (following a model of Lee et al. (2006)) and exponential. All shafts have the same volume and length.

Note that in the case of non-homogeneous materials and conical or exponential shafts, two distinct situations are possible. The material properties can increase or decrease in the direction of increasing cross-sectional area. In the following, these are referred to as ‘case 1‘ and ‘case 2‘, respectively.

For the linear taper the volume assumption leads to the following relations for the cross-sectional areas and area moments of inertia: (2)A(x)=A0s2[α+(1-α)xL]2I(x)=I0s4[α+(1-α)xL]4 where α is the ratio between the smallest to the largest radius of the shaft: α=R1/R2 and s=3/(α2+α+1).
For these shafts, cases 1 and 2 are specified via the parameter α, with 0<α<1 for case 1 (area increasing in the direction of increasing material properties) and α>1 for case 2 (area decreasing).

For the sinusoidal shafts the relations are (3)A(x)=A0s12[1+βsin(πxL)]2I(x)=I0s14[1+βsin(πxL)]4 where β is a numerical parameter controlling the sinusoidal profile (note that radii end values are the same), and s1=2π/(β2π+2π+8β) .
For the exponential shafts the relations for case 1 where s2=δ/(eδ-1), and for case 2 where s2=δ/(1-e-δ) are, respectively: (4)A(x)=A0s22eδxLI(x)=I0s24(eδxL)2 A(x)=A0s22e-δxLI(x)=I0s24(e-δxL)2
Here δ is an arbitrary real number which controls the exponential growth of the shaft profile.
Next, the FGMs are discussed.

sec.title: 3.1. FGM I
sec.p: For this model, following Chiu and Erdogan (1999), the material is assumed to be isotropic and non-homogeneous with properties given by (5)E(x)=E0(axL+1)mρ(x)=ρ0(axL+1)n where a, m and n are arbitrary real constants with a>-1 and E0 and ρ0 are the Young’s modulus and mass density at x=0.

A non-dimensional version of Equation (1) is developed next. By taking τ=Ω0t,ν=ΩΩ0,ξ=xL,Y=wL,I(x)=I0s4[α+(1-α)ξ]4=I0f2(ξ),A(x)=A0s2[α+(1-α)ξ]2=A0f4(ξ),E(x)=E0(aξ+1)m=E0f1(ξ),ρ(x)=ρ0(aξ+1)n=ρ0f3(ξ) and substituting into Equation (1), one obtains, for the linear taper case, (6)(E0I0ρ0A0L4Ω02)∂2∂ξ2(f1(ξ)f2(ξ)∂2Y∂ξ2)+(Fρ0A0L2Ω02)∂2Y∂ξ2 +f3(ξ)f4(ξ)∂2Y∂τ2=fρ0A0LΩ02 where Ω0 is a reference frequency (first bending frequency of a uniform pin-pin cylindrical shaft).
Also, one can take I(x)=I0s14[1+βsin(πξ)]4=I0f2(ξ)A(x)=A0s12[1+βsin(πξ)]2=A0f4(ξ) which allows Equation (6) to be used for the sinusoidal taper case.
Finally, one can take I(x)=I0s24e2δξ=I0f2(ξ)A(x)=A0s22eδξ=A0f4(ξ) in order to use Equation (6) for the exponential taper case.

In Equation (6), seeking natural frequencies and resonances, one can assume Y(ξ,τ)=S(ξ)sin(ντ) and harmonic external forcing f=fsin(ντ). This leads to (7)K1∂2∂ξ2(f1(ξ)f2(ξ)∂2S(ξ)∂ξ2)+F1∂2S(ξ)∂ξ2-ν2f3(ξ)f4(ξ)S(ξ)=F2 where K1=E0I0ρ0A0L4Ω02, F1=Fρ0A0L2Ω02 and F2=fρ0A0LΩ02.
Given the properties of the FGM and Equation (2) (or (3), or (4)), i.e. f1(ξ), f3(ξ), f2(ξ) and f4(ξ), numerical solutions for Equation (7) can, in principle, be obtained.

FGM I is taken to be a composite made from aluminum and silicon carbide. The properties of the material are given in Table 1 and are taken from Chiu and Erdogan (1999). Figure 3.
Shaft profiles I.

sec.title: 3.2. FGM II
sec.p: The second FGM model utilized assumes a composition derived from of a mixture of two materials, with the material variation given by a power-law gradient (see, for instance, Li (2008)). The material properties are given by (8)E(x)=Eb+(Et-Eb)(xL)λρ(x)=ρb+(ρt-ρb)(xL)λ where λ is a positive constant describing the volume fraction, which can be determined experimentally (Li, 2008). The subscripts b and t refer to the value of the parameter at x=0 and x=L, respectively. These values are those for the ‘pure’ materials involved in the composition of the FGM and are obtained from tables or manufacturer’s specifications. Here, the FGM is taken to be a mixture of aluminum and steel.
Taking Eb=γ1Et and ρb=γ2ρt, one can write (9)E(x)=Et[γ1+(1-γ1)ξλ]ρ(x)=ρt[γ2+(1-γ2)ξλ]
Equation (7) can still be used with the following modifications: (10)f1(ξ)=[γ1+(1-γ1)ξλ],f3(ξ)=[γ2+(1-γ2)ξλ],K1=EtI0ρtA0L4Ω02,F1=FρtA0L2Ω02andF2=fρtA0LΩ02.

sec.title: 4. Numerical results
sec.p: An analysis flowchart is given in Appendix A. The numerical values used in the simulations are L=0.896m and R=0.034950m. The properties of aluminum are E=0.71E11 N/m2 and ρ=2710kg/m3 and the properties of steel are E=2.10E11 N/m2 and ρ=7850kg/m3. The exact value of the first bending frequency of a homogeneous aluminum shaft with these dimensions can be calculated from (see, for example, Weaver et al. (1990)): Ω0=π2L2EI/ρA ≅175Hz.
The FGMs utilized are aluminum/silicon carbide (AlSiC – FGM I) and aluminum/Steel (AlSt – FGM II, Eb=EAluminum, ρb=ρAluminum).

sec.title: 4.1. Buckling load
sec.p: The value of the axial load F must be less than the static buckling load, which can be found from the equation: (11)K1∂2∂ξ2(f1(ξ)f2(ξ)∂2S(ξ)∂ξ2)+F1∂2S(ξ)∂ξ2=F2 subjected to pin–pin conditions and with F2=0.

Equation (11) does not in general possess an analytic solution and numerical approaches must be employed. Consider a point on the beam for the axial load that is less than critical. When the load passes through the critical value the displacement of the point undergoes a sign change. Evidence of this is presented below and in Appendix B. The approach here is as follows. Use is made of MAPLE®’s two-point boundary value problem package to solve a forced motion problem for various compressive loads. (Example MAPLE® worksheets for sections 4.1 and 4.2 are provided at: http://www.kettering.edu/∼amazzei/manuscript_public/FGM_tapered_shafts/.) One can infer a critical load by noting when an abrupt change in the sign of the deflection occurs. Note that higher modes could be obtained by extending the search range.

More evidence for the sign change can be found on inspecting some finite difference solutions for buckling. As shown, for example, in Borg (1990), the critical load Pcrit can be found from an equation in the form of a determinant equal to zero: |-[2-Δx2PcritEI]10…1-[2-Δx2PcritEI]…:::|=0
This yields a polynomial for determining Pcrit and so there is a sign change on passing through a root.
Note that the method has been shown to work well in practice for all cases in which it has been tested, although a proof is still lacking.

Figure 2 shows the results for a homogenous cylindrical pin–pin aluminum shaft. The critical load is approximately 1.0240 × 106 N. This result is in very good agreement with the theoretical Euler’s critical load for this problem (Pcrit=EIπ2/L2=1.0229E×106 N), which lends confidence to the numerical approach. Figure 2.
Aluminum shaft static deflection for increasing compressive loads.

For the conical shafts, case 1 is treated using α=0.5 and case 2 using α=2.0. This gives a shaft with small and large radii values around 35% less and 31% more than the cylindrical shaft value, respectively.
For the exponential shaft a value of δ=1.3 is used. This gives similar radii and a profile close to that of the conical shaft.

The profiles can be seen in Figure 3 (radius versus non-dimensional length, radii are normalized by the cylindrical value; red, cylindrical; green, conical; and blue, exponential). Table 1.
Material properties for the Al/SiC FGM
Aluminum / silicon carbide
E0 (GPa) 105.197
ρ0 (kg/m3) 2710.000
a 1.14568
m 1.00000
n 0.17611
υ 0.33

Utilizing the procedure described above for shafts made of both homogeneous and non-homogeneous materials, critical loads were calculated and are given in Table 2. The table shows that in all cases the use of a taper decreases the buckling load, a non-beneficial result. If tapers are mandated the user should be aware of this. Table 2.
Critical loads (N) for homogeneous and non-homogeneous cylindrical and tapered shafts: case 1 (α = 0.5, δ = 1.3), case 2 (α = 2.0, δ = 1.3)
Homogeneous shaft (Al) FGM I shaft (Al/SiC) FGM II shaft (Al/St)
Cylindrical Conical Exponential Cylindrical Conical Exponential Cylindrical Conical Exponential
Case 1 1.02 × 106 7.52 × 105 7.48 × 105 2.33 × 106 1.53 × 106 1.53 × 106 1.93 × 106 1.20 × 106 1.22 × 106
Case 2 1.02 × 106 7.52 × 105 7.48 × 105 2.33 × 106 1.90 × 106 1.87 × 106 1.93 × 106 1.64 × 106 1.61 × 106
For non-homogeneous materials, the table shows that in case 2, the use of the FGM is beneficial in that the decrease in the buckling load is considerably less when compared with the homogeneous case.

Note that for cylindrical shafts, the use of Al/SiC increases the load by approximately 128% when compared with pure aluminum. For Al/St the increase is about 89%. For conical and exponential shafts, the Al/SiC leads to an increase of approximately 103% and the Al/St leads to an increase of about 60%. As expected, since the conical and exponential profiles are very close in this case, no appreciable differences for the critical loads were found between them.

A question that arises is whether there is a situation when the use of an exponential taper can be more beneficial than a linear one. The answer is yes. For instance, for the cases described above, one can take α=0.2 and δ=2.5. This leads to shaft profiles as shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Shaft profiles II.

Results for the critical loads for this example are given in Table 3. Table 3.
Critical loads (N) for homogeneous and non-homogeneous conical and exponential shafts: case 1 (α = 0.2, δ = 2.5), case 2 (α = 5.0, δ = 2.5)
Homogeneous shaft (Al) FGM I shaft (Al/SiC) FGM II shaft (Al/St)
Conical Exponential Conical Exponential Conical Exponential
Case 1 2.40 × 105 3.38 × 105 4.28 × 105 6.47 × 105 3.18 × 105 4.96 × 105
Case 2 2.40 × 105 3.38 × 105 6.78 × 105 9.04 × 105 6.08 × 105 7.98 × 105

It is seen that the exponential profile can substantially increase the buckling loads for all material cases. For the homogeneous material the increase is about 41%. For the non-homogeneous materials, case 1 increases are 57% and 56% for Al/SiC and Al/St, respectively, and case 2 increases are 33% and 31%. Note, though, that as the tapering profile increases, the critical loads decrease substantially.

Next the case of non-homogeneous materials and sinusoidal shafts is considered. The parameter β controls the sinusoidal profile of the shaft and here, as an example, it is taken to be 1. This gives a shaft with a mid-radius that is twice the size of the end radii. The mid-radius is around 20% more and the end radii around 40% less than the cylindrical shaft value.

Using the above procedure the critical loads were calculated and are shown in Table 4. Table 4.
Critical loads (N) for homogeneous and non-homogeneous cylindrical and sinusoidal shafts: β = 1.0
Homogeneous shaft (Al) FGM I shaft (Al/SiC) FGM II shaft (Al/St)
Cylindrical Sinusoidal Cylindrical Sinusoidal Cylindrical Sinusoidal
β=1 1.02 × 106 1.32 × 106 2.33 × 106 2.88 × 106 1.93 × 106 2.29 × 106
Note that for pure aluminum, the sinusoidal shaft increases the buckling load by 29% when compared with the cylindrical shaft.

For the non-homogeneous materials results are as follows. For Al/SiC, the sinusoidal shaft gives an increase of 24% for the first critical load when compared with the cylindrical shaft. Similarly, for the Al/St the increase is 19%.
Also, the use of an Al/SiC sinusoidal shaft in place of a pure aluminum sinusoidal shaft can lead to an increase in the load of about 118%. In the case of Al/St this increase can be about 73%.
These are all beneficial results and demonstrate that both changes in profile and material can drastically improve the critical buckling load.

sec.title: 4.2. Frequencies
sec.p: Next the influences of the FGM, and shaft profiles, on the first bending frequency are investigated. In the subsequent numerical simulations, the values for the compressive load are chosen to be 80% of the smallest critical value for the particular material group, i.e. Al, Al/SiC and Al/St.
Equation (7), with F2=0, must be solved subjected to pin–pin boundary conditions. This again, in general, does not have analytic solutions.

Several observations on some characteristics of resonances should be made. Resonances of algebraic type show up as zeros in denominators. Hence passing through resonance is accompanied by a sign change. A problem is encountered here in that the ‘built-in’ MAPLE® eigenvalue solver gives only the trivial solution. The strategy employed here is similar to that used in buckling. Use is made of MAPLE®’s two-point boundary value solver to solve a forced motion problem. It consists of assuming a constant value for the forcing function F2 and varying the frequency ν. By observing the mid-span deflection, the resonant frequency can be found on noting where an abrupt change in sign occurs. The sign change on passing through resonance is illustrated using a rod problem in Appendix C. (A URL for MAPLE® worksheets is provided in Section 4.1.) Note that higher modes could be obtained by extending the search range.

For a pure aluminum cylindrical shaft, an analytical solution involving the frequency ν can be found using MAPLE®. Figure 5 shows a plot of the mid-span deflection, as a function of the frequency ν, clearly showing a resonance at ν=0.65 (non-dimensional frequency corresponds to approximately 113.75 Hz). Figure 5.
Shaft deflections at mid-span as a function of ν..

In the following the numerical method described above is tested against this value. Assuming a value of 1 for the external forcing and varying ν, the resultant deflections are plotted and investigated. Figure 6 shows these deflections for two distinct values of the frequency (close to the resonant value estimated above). Note that the figure confirms the value 0.65 as the resonant frequency, lending confidence to the procedure.

Figure 7 shows the deflections for the conical Al/SiC shaft for α=0.5. Resonance is seen around ν=0.60. Proceeding in this fashion, resonance values were calculated and the results are given in Table 5. It is seen that conical or exponential tapering of a shaft consistently reduces the frequency of the fundamental mode. Figure 6.
Aluminum cylindrical shaft deflections for ν=0.64 and 0.65, respectively.
Table 5.
Resonance frequencies (Hz) for homogeneous and non-homogeneous shafts: case 1 (α = 0.5, δ = 1.3), case 2 (α = 2.0, δ = 1.3) and F1=0.8Fc (Fc, smallest critical load for material group)
Homogeneous Shaft (Al) FGM I shaft (Al/SiC) FGM II shaft (Al/St)
Cylindrical Conical Exponential Cylindrical Conical Exponential Cylindrical Conical Exponential
Case 1 113.75 73.50 73.50 176.75 105.00 105.00 124.25 71.75 73.50
Case 2 113.75 73.50 73.50 176.75 147.00 143.51 124.25 108.50 106.76
Note that the cylindrical Al/SiC shaft increases the frequency by about 55% when compared with the aluminum one. The Al/St gives an increase of about 9%.

For the conical shafts and case 1, the Al/SiC increases the frequency by about 43% while the Al/St practically does not change it (2.4% variation). For case 2 the Al/SiC gives an increase of 100% while the Al/St shows an increase of about 48%. The frequencies for the exponential shafts are close to the conical ones (just a little smaller for case 2) and, again, these results are expected since the profiles are similar. On the other hand, note the results for the case where the profiles are seen on Figure 4. These are shown in Table 6. Here the change in profile leads to substantial frequency increases. For the aluminum shaft an increase of 52% is observed. For the Al/SiC shaft the increases are 60% and 17% for cases 1 and 2, respectively, whereas for the Al/St shaft these are 63% and 12%. Hence, similar to the critical load cases, there can be instances when the exponential profile can be more beneficial than the conical one. Table 6.
Resonance frequency (Hz) for homogeneous and non-homogeneous conical and exponential shafts: case 1 (α = 0.2, δ = 2.5), case 2 (α = 5.0, δ = 2.5) and F1=0.8Fc (Fc, smallest critical load for material group)
Homogeneous shaft (Al) FGM I shaft (Al/SiC) FGM II shaft (Al/St)
Conical Exponential Conical Exponential Conical Exponential
Case 1 57.75 87.51 78.75 126.01 52.50 85.76
Case 2 57.75 87.51 136.51 159.26 103.26 115.51
The results demonstrate that the FGM can lead to increases in the frequency and can be advantageous for shaft applications, under compressive loads, that require this goal.

The procedure given above was also utilized for obtaining the frequencies of the sinusoidal shafts (with f2(ξ)=s14[1+βsin(πξ)]4 and f4(ξ)=s12[1+βsin(πξ)]2 in Equation (7)). The results are in Table 7. Table 7.
Resonance frequency (Hz) for homogeneous and non-homogeneous cylindrical and sinusoidal shafts: β = 1.0 and F1=0.8Fc (Fc, smallest critical load for material group)
Homogeneous shaft (Al) FGM I shaft (Al/SiC) FGM II shaft (Al/St)
Cylindrical Sinusoidal Cylindrical Sinusoidal Cylindrical Sinusoidal
β=1 113.75 171.50 176.75 203.00 124.25 140.00
Comparing the homogeneous shafts, note that the sinusoidal profile increases the first bending frequency by 51%.
In the case of the non-homogeneous shafts, the Al/SiC sinusoidal one increases the frequency by 15% and the Al/St by 13%.

Here, the use of an Al/SiC sinusoidal shaft in place of an aluminum sinusoidal shaft can lead to an increase in the first frequency of about 26%. On the other hand, the use of Al/St decreases the frequency by 13%.
With the exception of the Al/St, the remainder results are all very beneficial and, again, demonstrate the usefulness of changes in profile and material with the objective of frequency increase.

As a final check, note that Equation (6) could be tackled directly in order to verify the resonance frequency values. Although numerically intensive, this could reinforce the results obtained using the numerical technique described above. Thus, as an example, results obtained using MAPLE®’s PDE solver (with the appropriate boundary conditions for this case) are given in the following. For the Al/SiC shaft case 1 and exponential profile, Table 6 shows a resonance frequency value of about 126 Hz. Solutions are then sought for forcing frequencies close to this value and away from it, for instance 87.50 Hz (ν=0.50) and 126 Hz (ν=0.72).

Figures 8 and 9 show shaft deflections (non-dimensional) as a function of the axial coordinate for five different values of time, for non-resonant and resonant frequency values, respectively. Note that the maximum deflection in the resonant case is about six times larger than that in the non-resonant case. This indicates that the 126 Hz value is a resonance frequency. These results confirm the above predictions and provide confidence in the numerical technique employed.

The discussion above concerned the first bending frequencies of the shafts for fixed values of the compressive axial force (taken to be 80% of the lowest value of the critical load for the specific material type group). Figure 7.
Aluminum silicon carbide conical shaft deflections for ν=0.59 and 0.60, respectively.
Figure 8.
Aluminum/silicon carbide deflections at non-resonant frequency.
In the following a brief exploration of the effect of varying compressive forces on the shafts’ frequencies is conducted.

Figure 10 shows the influence of increasing axial force on the first bending frequency (non-dimensional) of the Al/SiC conical shaft for four distinct cases: α = 0.2, α = 0.5 (both corresponding to case 1, where the area of the shaft’s cross section increases with increasing material properties) and α = 5.0, α = 2.0 (both corresponding to case 2, where the area of the shaft’s cross section decreases with increasing material properties). It is seen that for all cases the frequency decreases as the axial load increases. For example, for case 1 and α = 0.2, the frequency decreases approximately 22.5% when the axial load increases by a factor of 5. Note that the figure shows that the frequency behavior is not linear in nature. Figure 9.
Aluminum/silicon carbide deflections at resonant frequency.

Similar results can be seen in Figure 11, which shows the frequency variation as a function of the axial force for the Al/St conical shaft. Note that cases 1 and 2 used here are the same as discussed above. A frequency decrease with increasing axial load is also observed in these cases. Figure 10.
Frequency variation as a function of axial force – FGM I, linear taper.

The sinusoidal profile is considered next. The variation of the shaft’s frequencies, for FGM I, is shown in Figure 12. The same trend of frequency decrease with increasing load is observed. In this case, for instance, the frequency decreases by 11.5 % when the load increases by a factor of 5. Figure 11.
Frequency variation as a function of axial force – FGM II, linear taper.
Results not given here show that the frequencies for the FGM shafts with exponential profile behave in the same manner.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: It is seen that the use of conical and exponential tapering consistently decreases the critical buckling load. This is generally a non-beneficial result and a user should be aware of it if a taper is needed. Conical and exponential tapers also consistently reduce the frequency of the fundamental transverse vibration mode. Conversely, a sinusoidally varying profile consistently increases both the critical buckling load and the frequency of the fundamental vibration mode.

For the cases studied, the use of FGM can be useful for shaft applications, either cylindrical or tapered, where the shaft is under compressive loads. Here the majority of the results show beneficial trends. For shafts under axial loads, the use of FGM with tapering can lead to improvements in terms of increases both in critical buckling loads and first bending frequencies.
Note that for all cases studied, increases in the axial compressive loads led to decreases in the shafts’ first bending frequencies.
A summary of the results is given in the following.

For cylindrical shafts, for the case studied, the use of an Al/SiC shaft increases the critical buckling load by approximately 128% when compared with a pure aluminum one. For an Al/St shaft the increase is about 89%.

For conical shafts, the Al/SiC leads to an increase of approximately 103% and the Al/St leads to an increase of about 60%, when the material properties are increasing with increasing cross-sectional area (case 1). For the case where the material properties are decreasing (case 2), the increase in the critical load is about 153% and 118% for the Al/SiC and Al/St, respectively.

For exponential profile shafts it was shown that there are cases where this profile can be more beneficial than a conical one. For instance, for aluminum shafts and the case studied, the increase in the critical load was about 41%. For the non-homogeneous materials, case 1 increases were 57% and 56% for Al/SiC and Al/St, respectively, and case 2 increases were 33% and 31%.

In the case of sinusoidal shafts made of aluminum, it was shown that increases in the buckling load of the order of 29% are possible when compared with cylindrical shafts. Al/SiC sinusoidal shafts show an increase of 24% on the load, whereas Al/St shafts show about 19%.
The use of an Al/SiC sinusoidal shaft in place of a pure aluminum shaft can lead to an increase in the load of about 118%. In the case of Al/St this increase can be about 73%.
Regarding the first bending frequency, the cylindrical Al/SiC shaft leads to a frequency increase of 55% when compared with the aluminum one. The Al/St gives a frequency increase of about 9%.

For conical shafts and case 1, the Al/SiC allows for a frequency increase of 43% while the Al/St practically gives no change (2.4%). In case 2 the Al/SiC allows for a frequency increase of 100% while the Al/St shows an increase of about 48%. Variations for the exponential profile were close to the conical one.

For the case of the exponential profile shown in Figure 4 and aluminum shafts, an increase of 52% was observed. For the Al/SiC shafts the increases were 60% and 17% for cases 1 and 2, respectively, and for the Al/St shaft these were 63% and 12%.
In the case of homogeneous sinusoidal shafts, the sinusoidal profile gives an increase in the first bending frequency of about 51%.

For non-homogeneous sinusoidal shafts, the Al/SiC one increases the frequency by 15% and the Al/St by 13%. The use of an Al/SiC sinusoidal shaft in place of an aluminum one leads to an increase in the first frequency of 26%. However, the use of Al/St decreases the frequency by 13%.

Increases in the axial loads cause decreases in the shafts’ first bending frequencies. For instance, for an Al/SiC shaft, case 1 and α = 2.0, a five-fold increase in the load leads to a decrease in frequency of about 23%.

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: area of the shaft cross section (A0 initial value);
Young’s modulus (E0,Et,Eb, Young’s modulus values for different non-homogenous materials);
axial compressive force acting on the shaft;
external transverse force per unit length acting on the shaft;
non-dimensional lowest critical buckling load for a material group;
area moment of inertia of the shaft cross section (I0 initial value);
shaft displacement in the y direction;
non-dimensional shaft displacement in the y direction;
numerical parameter (controls the sinusoidal shaft profile);
arbitrary real number (controls exponential growth of the shaft profile);
mass density (ρ0,ρt,ρb, density values for different non-homogenous materials);
reference frequency: first bending frequency of a pin-pin homogeneous shaft;

sec.title: Appendix B. Model problem: buckling load
sec.p: For constant material properties and no tapering, the equation describing buckling of a beam is (12)∂4w(x)∂x4+FEI∂2w(x)∂x2=0
The analytic solution to this equation is given by w(x)=C1+C2x+C3cospx+C4sinpx, where Ci are constants determined via the problem boundary conditions (BCs) and p=F/EI.
For pin–pin BC, the buckling loads and associated mode shapes are given by p=nπ,n=1,2,3…,w(x)=C2[x-sin(px)/sin(p)]

Setting C2 = 1.0 and x = ½, the normalized shape amplitude at the center of the beam is seen in Figure 13, which shows a sign change on passing through the critical load (n = 1.0 gives p = 9.87).Figure 12.
Frequency variation as a function of axial force – FGM I, sinusoidal taper.Figure 14.
Mode shape as a function of ωd for xd = ½.

Note that the same conclusion would be drawn from plots at other x locations. The only exception would be for a point with an identically zero displacement (node), but there are no nodes in the lowest mode.

sec.title: Appendix C. Model problem: resonance frequency
sec.p: The equation describing longitudinal vibrations of a cylindrical rod with constant material properties and varying cross-sectional area A is (13)∂∂x(EA(x)∂u(x,t)∂x)=ρA(x)∂2u(x,t)∂t2
Taking u(x,t)=S(x)[A1cos(ωt)+A2sin(ωt)] leads to (14)ddx(EA(x)dS(x)dx)+ρA(x)ω2S(x)=0
Assuming an exponential variation for the area A=A0exp(λx), Equation (14), in non-dimensional form, becomes (15)d2Sd(xd)dxd2+αddSd(xd)dxd+ωd2Sd(z)=0 where Sd=S/L, xd=x/L, αd=λL and ωd2=ω2L2ρ/E.
The analytic solution to Equation (15) is given by Sd(xd)=B1exp[(-12αd+12αd2-4ωd2)xd] +B2exp[(-12αd-12αd2-4ωd2)xd] where B1 and B2 are constants determined via boundary conditions.
Taking pin–pin BCs, for example, the frequencies and associated mode shapes are given by ωd=n2π2+αd24,n=1,2,3…;Sd(xd)=C1exp(-12αd)[2sin(124ωd2-αd2)xd]

Setting C1 = 1.0, αd = 2.0 and xd = ½, the mode shape amplitude at the center of the rod is seen in Figure 14, which shows a sign change on passing through the resonance frequency (for n = 1.0, ωd=3.30).Figure 13.
Buckling shape as a function of p for x = ½.
